title: Researchers use superheated steam to sanitize dry food manufacturing plants - Food Safety News
summary: Cornell University researchers are developing superheated steam for cleaning in dry food processing plants to prevent contamination. The research aims to enhance food safety in various industries and reduce the demand for water and sanitizers.
green_innovation: TRUE. This innovation contributes to environmental sustainability goals by using superheated steam to clean dry food processing plants, reducing the risk of contamination and promoting sustainability through decreased water usage and waste management.
business_innovation: TRUE. The introduction of superheated steam as a cleaning method in dry food processing plants represents a new business process that significantly differs from traditional cleaning methods to improve food safety.
green_product: FALSE. The article does not focus on a specific good or service designed, manufactured, and used in a way that significantly reduces its environmental impact throughout its life cycle.
green_process: TRUE. The use of superheated steam to clean dry food processing plants aligns with the definition of a green process as it minimizes environmental impacts by reducing waste, conserving resources, and limiting the release of harmful substances.
likely_naics_codes: Likely NAICS Codes: 311991 - Perishable Prepared Food Manufacturing, 311999 - All Other Miscellaneous Food Manufacturing, 221118 - Other Electric Power Generation, 325998 - All Other Miscellaneous Chemical Product and Preparation Manufacturing
greenwashing: FALSE. The article provides factual information about the research on using superheated steam in dry food processing plants and does not involve deceptive marketing tactics about environmental benefits.
